review.title: Multi-resource defensive strategies for patrolling games with alarm systems
review.abstract: Security Games employ game theoretical tools to derive resource allocation strategies in security domains. Recent works considered the presence of alarm systems, even suffering various forms of uncertainty, and showed that disregarding alarm signals may lead to arbitrarily bad strategies. The central problem with an alarm system, unexplored in other Security Games, is finding the best strategy to respond to alarm signals for each mobile defensive resource. The literature provides results for the basic single-resource case, showing that even in that case the problem is computationally hard. In this paper, we focus on the challenging problem of designing algorithms scaling with multiple resources. First, we focus on finding the minimum number of resources assuring non-null protection to every target. Then, we deal with the computation of multi-resource strategies with different degrees of coordination among resources. For each considered problem, we provide a computational analysis and propose algorithmic methods.

sections.heading: 5 Overall resolution approach
sections.text: The contributions we have made are organized in the solution approach outlined in Figure 1. Let's start by solving the problem of finding the minimum resource placement by solving the associated SET-COVER formulation (or our polynomic algorithm with trees and cycles). If the problem cannot be solved exactly in a short time, we apply the greedy approximation algorithm of [Chvatal, 1979] and then apply a simple local search to improve the greedy solution. Once this step is complete, we have determined a number of resources and we solve the problem of finding the best allocation strategy for them. As mentioned above, the best allocation strategy, when no signal is triggered, is to place the m resources statically in the best coverage placement. Such placement is defined as the one from which the signal response game delivers the maximum expected benefit.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and future research
sections.text: In this thesis, we considered a security game with the presence of a spatially imperfect alarm system and addressed the novel generalization of settings in which the Defender can control multiple mobile resources. We proposed a solution for dealing with the new algorithmic problems that such a generalization entails. First, we addressed the problem of calculating the minimum number of resources required in a given environment, and then determining the best signal response strategy among different resource coordination schemes. Future research will include adapting our algorithms to cases where the number of resources available to D is greater than the resources required for minimal coverage of the placement. In addition, we plan to work on the model by allowing the presence of mispositions and missed detections in the alarm systems as well as the presence of multiple resources on the part of the attacker. These enhancements are, of course, driven by real requirements that security games must meet.
